awd_titl_txt: Integrated Adaptations to Moisture Supply and Cross-over in Whole-plant Growth among Eucalyptus Species Along an Australian Rainfall Gradient
awd_abstract_narration:
Land plants face a fundamental tradeoff: to acquire the carbon dioxide needed to photosynthesize and grow, they must expose their moist, living cells to a dry atmosphere, which causes enormous losses of water. Any adjustment to minimize water loss comes at the price of slower intake of carbon. Theory suggests that roughly 20 traits involving plant morphology, physiology, and leaf structure should vary with moisture supply in order to maximize whole-plant height growth and survival. This study will examine all these traits in ten species of Eucalyptus (one of the most widely planted genera of trees on Earth) that differ in their distribution across a rainfall gradient from temperate rain forest to semi-desert in Victoria, Australia. Plants will be grown in four common gardens that span this gradient. Measurements of photosynthetic and water transport capacity will be made regularly and periodic harvests will be used to assess morphology and rates of growth. This project is pioneering for understanding adaptation to moisture supply, because it combines a novel theoretical approach with the use of common gardens to test for potential forces shaping species distributions. This project will train a postdoc, at least one graduate student, and multiple undergraduates. The results will help to understand plant response to prolonged and severe droughts, and distribution in arid regions. A multimedia presentation on Eucalyptus adaptation to moisture supply will be made for public television, and a capstone field course will be offered through UW-Madison and U Sydney that will focus on plant adaptation and community ecology.

Plant survival, growth, adaptation, and integration of roughly 20 traits involving photosynthesis, hydraulics, and resource allocation will be studied in ten Eucalyptus species, stratified phylogenetically and by dominance of successive bands of annual rainfall in Victoria, Australia.  Measurements will be made over two 2-year experiments at four common gardens spanning this gradient. Phylogenetically structured tests of adaptation and functional integration will be conducted, asking whether the observed shifts tend to maximize rates of height growth, whether patterns of plasticity within species in response to moisture supply conflict with those seen across species, and whether species show evidence of adaptive cross-over, with taxa having an advantage in height growth or survival only under conditions similar to those they dominate in nature.  A direct experimental test of competitive success at each common garden will be compared with expectations based on growth rates of uncrowded monocultures and theoretical predictions based on plant traits. The proposed research is novel for studying plant adaptation to moisture supply, in terms of the range of traits whose adaptation and integration will be examined, the use of common gardens to test for cross-over in height growth as support for adaptation and a potential force shaping species distributions, and the use of growth models to identify key traits and trait aggregates that affect plant growth.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past six years, we tested the importance of adaptation, growth, and survival in determining the distributions of Eucalyptus species that dominate different portions of a climatic moisture gradient from semi-deserts to temperate rainforests in Victoria, Australia. Relative moisture supply was quantified as P/Ep (where P is annual precipitation and Ep is annual pan evaporation) for each common garden, and for each species averaged across its range.  

Across the globe, terrestrial plants must balance the photosynthetic benefits of traits against the costs of water loss inevitably associated with CO2 uptake. Optimality models assume traits vary with moisture supply to maximize growth and local competitive ability, and then predict relationships among species distributions, growth rates, traits, and environmental conditions. We tested such predictions for an unprecedented number of traits (and the usually untested optimality assumption) by measuring the survival, growth, and 50 photosynthetic, hydraulic, and allocational traits of ten Eucalyptus species grown in four common gardens along an 8-fold natural gradient P/Ep in Victoria. Species were stratified by subgenus and their dominance of different portions of the P/Ep gradient (Fig. 1).

We found that most trait-environment relationships accord qualitatively with theory and appear adaptive, often with weaker relationships within species across gardens (plasticity) than across species within gardens (reflecting fixed genetic differences). In all, 98% of relationships within species across gardens (reflecting plasticity in response to site P/Ep) are consistent with theory, as well as 85% of relationships across species within gardens (reflecting fixed genetic differences in response to species P/Ep).

Paradoxically, in drier gardens species from moister climates have lower stomatal conductance g than others (Fig. 2). Most previous models for optimal stomatal conductance predict that it should increase as moisture supply increases and the consequent cost of replacing water decreases. Responses in this and four related traits may reflect variation across species in what we term mesophyll photosynthetic sensitivity (MPS) – the rate of decline in photosynthetic capacity at a cellular or tissue level with drops in leaf water potential as plants dry out, after factoring out the effects of g itself. We found that species from moister climates show greater MPS, and that MPS increases in predictable fashion with species P/Ep (Fig. 3). The greater photosynthetic resilience of species from drier climates comes, however, at the cost of lower maximum rates of photosynthesis per unit leaf mass at full hydration (Salvi et al. 2021).

Declines in stomatal conductance with species P/Ep within gardens, as well as increases in g with site P/Ep, were predicted by Givnish (1986) but not Cowan and Farquhar (1977). We also found, as predicted, that under a given set of conditions, species from moister climates regulate their stomatal conductance and leaf water potential within narrower ranges (Salvi et al. 2022). Given the fundamental importance of stomatal conductance in regulating photosynthesis, water loss from natural and agricultural ecosystems, and climate at regional and global scales, these findings – and especially, those bearing on MPS – have profound importance.

Our field experiment supports adaptive cross-over, with realized height growth (H* = height x survival) of focal species generally exceeding that of others in climates that the focal species dominate in nature (Fig. 4). The patterns observed in H* reflect complex relationships of height growth and survival to species and site P/Ep. Height growth increases with species and garden P/Ep; survival rate declines with species P/Ep in drier gardens while increasing in moister gardens.

Our demonstration of the pervasive importance of photosynthetic, hydraulic, and allocational adaptations in determining species distributions along a climatic moisture gradient is the most powerful such analysis to date linking ecophysiology to plant species distributions and points the way to similar approaches that could be taken in other systems to test the roles of adaptation and plasticity in setting species distributions.

Our demonstration that mesophyll photosynthetic sensitivity (MPS) is less in plants from drier environments, but at the cost of decreased maximum rates of photosynthesis at full tissue hydration compared with species from moister habitats documents a fundamentally important trade-off underlying the ecology and evolution of land plants, with far-reaching implications for the rise of many different adaptations related to energy capture, the determinants of plant productivity, and the tradeoffs underlying the differential distributions of plant species. It may also have profound significance for the development of arid-land crops and timber-producing trees.

This project resulted in 73 publications, training of a post-doc, a Ph.D., and several undergrads in physiological ecology and comparative biology, and offering an undergraduate/graduate research field course on Australian plant ecology. Given that much of the massive radiation of Eucalyptus (ca. 700 spp., Australia's dominant tree genus, widely grown across the world for timber and oils) is likely to involve adaptation to different levels of moisture supply, our findings should greatly interest ecologists, physiologists, foresters, and evolutionary biologists.
